Term.definition: A multidimensional array object provided by the NumPy library for efficient numerical computations.
A clustering algorithm that partitions data into a specified number of clusters based on similarity.
A structured collection of data, often used for training or evaluating machine learning models.
A two-dimensional array of numbers, often used to represent data or mathematical operations.
A Python data structure that stores key-value pairs for fast lookup.
An array-like data structure, often used to represent a sequence of values.
Function that converts text data into numerical feature vectors for machine learning models.
A Python library for numerical computations, especially with arrays and matrices.
A boolean array used to select or filter elements in another array.
The task of assigning input data to one of several predefined categories or classes.
The process of identifying patterns or objects within input data, such as images or sounds.
The process of rescaling input data to a specific range, often [0,1] or [-1,1].
A Python library for efficient numerical computations and handling of large, multi-dimensional arrays.
Also called dot product; multiplies two vectors to produce a single number.
An ordered array of numbers representing a point or direction in space.
A two-dimensional array of numbers arranged in rows and columns.
Process of rescaling data to have mean 0 and standard deviation 1.
Central points representing clusters in clustering algorithms, used to assign data points to the nearest cluster.
Grouping data points so that those in the same group are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.
Technique for compressing data by mapping vectors to a finite set of representative vectors.
Center points of clusters, often representing average values in clustering algorithms like k-means.
A popular clustering algorithm that partitions data into k distinct groups based on similarity.
A metric for measuring straight-line distance between two points in Euclidean space.
A non-invasive technique for recording magnetic fields produced by brain activity.
A sequence of data points collected or recorded at successive points in time.
A function that calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it into smaller subproblems.
An object created from a class; a specific realization of a class in memory.
The output category assigned to an object by a classification algorithm.
A terminal node in a tree structure that contains a final value or class label.
A mathematical or computational representation of a real-world process used for prediction or analysis.
A machine learning technique that groups similar data points together without predefined labels.
A machine learning approach where models are trained using labeled input-output pairs.
Values in a model that are learned from data to optimize predictions.
The process of adjusting parameters to improve a model's performance based on a chosen metric.
Random or irrelevant variations in feature data that can reduce model accuracy.
A measure of impurity or disorder used to evaluate splits in decision trees.
The reduction in entropy after a dataset is split on an attribute.
A function or condition used to test or divide data in algorithms.
The target value or category assigned to a data instance in classification tasks.
A neural network where connections move only forward from input to output layers, no cycles or loops.
A machine learning type where models train on labeled data with known outputs.
A function applied to neuron outputs to introduce non-linearity in neural networks.
The final layer in a neural network, producing the network's predictions.
Intermediate layers in a neural network between input and output layers, enabling complex representations.
Also called dot product; multiplies two vectors, resulting in a scalar or another vector.
An operation that flips a matrix over its diagonal, swapping rows and columns.
A measure of uncertainty or impurity in a dataset, used in information theory and decision trees.
A tree-like model used for decision making and classification in machine learning.
An unsupervised machine learning algorithm for partitioning data into k clusters based on feature similarity.
A NumPy function that changes the shape of an array without changing its data.
A mathematical representation used to make predictions or decisions based on data.
Groups of similar data points identified by a clustering algorithm in unsupervised learning.
An individual measurable property or characteristic of a phenomenon being observed.
Data that includes both input values and the corresponding correct output (target) values.
Data that includes input values but lacks corresponding correct output (target) values.
A mathematical function applied to neural network outputs to introduce non-linearity.
The first layer of a neural network that receives the input data.
The final layer of a neural network that produces the prediction or result.
Neurons in layers between input and output layers, enabling complex representations.
A model that assigns input data to one of several predefined categories.
A classification algorithm that assigns labels based on the closest data points in feature space.
A model or algorithm that assigns categories or labels to data based on input features.
A two-dimensional array where rows are samples and columns are features describing each sample.
A value or label indicating the category to which a data sample belongs.
A systematic error introduced by non-random sampling or data collection methods.
A technique that makes recommendations by analyzing preferences or behavior of multiple users.
A software tool that suggests items to users based on data analysis and prediction.
Branching diagrams showing evolutionary relationships among species based on genetic or physical traits.
Changes in the DNA sequence where one nucleotide is replaced by another.
The process of drawing conclusions from data using statistical methods.
Statistical models with parameters organized at multiple levels, often representing nested data structures.
A measure of impurity or disorder used in decision tree algorithms to split data.
A value used as a cutoff to divide data based on a specific condition.
A boolean array used to filter or select elements from another array based on a condition.
Algorithm for training neural networks by adjusting weights based on error gradients.
Neural network type where connections move in one direction, from input to output, without cycles.
A type of machine learning where the model finds patterns in data without labeled outputs.
Points representing the centers of clusters in clustering algorithms like k-means.
An ordered array of numbers representing data points in mathematics or programming.
A function that defines the distance between elements in a space.
A subset of data used to train a machine learning model.
A function measuring the error between predicted and actual values in a model.
In classification, the distance from a data point to the decision boundary.
A single cycle of a repeated process, often in optimization algorithms.
An error when a calculation exceeds the maximum value a variable can store.
A mathematical operation involving raising one number to the power of another.
A flat subspace dividing a high-dimensional space into two parts, used for classification.
Measures of how a function changes as its input changes; used for optimization in machine learning.
A model that separates data into classes using a linear decision boundary.
A problem where gradients grow too large during training, causing unstable learning.
Models that predict continuous values instead of class labels.
A simple neural network with one layer, used for linear classification tasks.
An ordered one-dimensional array of numbers, often used to represent data or features.
A value that identifies the category or group an object belongs to in classification tasks.
A unique value or code representing a specific class in classification problems.
A function that defines the distance or similarity between two data points.
An algorithm that produces the same output for a given input every time, with no randomness.
The process of using data and algorithms to forecast future outcomes or trends.
The topmost node in a tree structure, representing the starting point of the tree.
A smaller group of elements selected from a larger set, often based on specific criteria.
A category or label assigned to data points, often representing target values in classification tasks.
A mathematical function applied to a neuron's output to introduce non-linearity into the network.
The process of assigning initial values to neural network weights before training begins.
A vector containing the weights or coefficients for each feature in a linear model.
A function that measures the difference between predicted and actual values in a model.
A function to split data into training and testing subsets for model evaluation.
A loss function for classification tasks, measuring the performance of a model whose output is a probability.
A loss function using the sigmoid activation, often for binary classification tasks.
A parameter representing the learning rate, controlling the step size in gradient descent.
A field of artificial intelligence focused on teaching computers to learn from data and make predictions.
A variable representing the target category or label in classification tasks.
Features or input variables used to predict the target variable in a model.
A calculation involving numbers with fractional parts, represented in computer memory as floats.
The probability of observed data given a particular class or parameter.
The initial probability assigned to a class before observing any data.
Updated probabilities of classes after considering the observed data.
Function to split data into training and testing subsets for model evaluation.
A class representing a neural network model, often used for classification or regression tasks.
A probability distribution describing outcomes of experiments with more than two possible categories.
The bottom part of a fraction, representing the total or whole in probability calculations.
A collection of data, often organized in rows and columns, used for analysis or training models.
Target values that indicate the category or class for each data sample in classification tasks.
A data type representing categories without any order or ranking among them.
A classifier that uses distance measures between objects to assign class labels.
A tree data structure where edges have a direction, from parent to child nodes.
The topmost node in a tree, from which all other nodes descend.
Nodes in a tree that have at least one child and are not leaves or the root.
Terminal nodes in a tree that do not have any children.
Nodes at the end of a tree path, representing final outcomes or classes.
A function or condition that returns true or false, used to split data in decision trees.
A machine learning algorithm that classifies data based on the closest training examples.
Training dataset containing input features used to fit a model.
Labels or target values for the training dataset.
Test dataset containing input features for evaluating a model.
Predicted labels for the test dataset, generated by a model.
True labels for the test dataset, used to evaluate predictions.
A popular Python library for machine learning, providing tools for data analysis and modeling.
A mathematical function used to measure similarity or difference between data points.
Groups of similar data points identified in a dataset based on certain characteristics.
A technique for evaluating model performance by splitting data into training and testing sets multiple times.
A function to divide data into training and testing subsets for model evaluation.
The ratio of true positives to all predicted positives; measures classification accuracy.
The ratio of true positives to all actual positives; measures the ability to find all relevant cases.
A function that computes the straight-line distance between two points in Euclidean space.
A function that computes the sum of absolute differences between coordinates, also called Manhattan distance.
An algorithmic approach that makes the locally optimal choice at each step, hoping for a global optimum.
Solutions that are best within a neighboring set of solutions, but not necessarily the best overall.
When a model learns the training data too well, including noise, reducing its generalization to new data.
Data that is divided into discrete categories or groups, each with a finite set of possible values.
The process of passing input data through a neural network to generate predictions.
A special block in Python scripts that runs code only when the script is executed directly.
